Dialogue.Stage Direction: As the time rotor goes gently up and down, the Doctor is lying on the floor playing chess with K9.

Dialogue.Line: Rook to bishop's four.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He stops his clock and starts K9's.

Dialogue.Line: I saw Capablanca make that move against Alekhine in 1927. K9: He lost, master.
Who? K9: Capablanca.
Are you sure? K9: Master, I have been programmed with all the Championship games since 1866. Capablanca lost.
I must have been called away. Are you really sure? K9: King to knight's two.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor moves the white King for him.

Dialogue.Line: King to knight's two. King? That's a terrible move. You've weakened the king's side. K9: Clock, master.
I know, I know. I'll check your programming sometime. We're not supposed to be playing draughts, you know. K9: Master.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Romana enters, wearing her original long white gown.

Dialogue.Line: What are you doing, Doctor?
Shush. We're playing chess.
Yes, I can see that, but aren't you forgetting something?
I don't think so.
What about our task? The Key to Time, remember?
Oh, that old thing.
Yes, that old thing. The Guardian did stress the need for urgency, didn't he?
Shush.
I'll do it.
If you must.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Romana puts the tracer into the hole in the console.

Dialogue.Line: I just feel I deserve a little break. After all, we've got half the segments. I prefer to play chess.
Really. Materialisation in fifteen seconds. Mate in twelve. K9: Correction, mistress. Eleven.
Eleven? Oh yes. Sorry, K9. K9: Apologies are unnecessary, mistress.
Mate in eleven? Oh yes, oh yes. Well, that's the trouble with chess, isn't it. It's all so predictable.
Materialisation commencing now. Five, four, three, two, one.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Romana gently pulls back a control and the Tardis appears amongst a stand of silver birch.

Dialogue.Line: Was that smooth enough for you, Doctor?
Hmm?
I said, was that smooth enough?
Mate in eleven? What, have we arrived? Oh good. Where?
Tara.
Tara?
Earth-type gravity, oxygen atmosphere, climate, temperate.
Ah. Peaceful looking place. That shouldn't give you too much trouble.
Me?
I think it's rather beautiful, don't you? Very good for. Yes, I think it would be.
What?
Shouldn't you be getting changed?
Oh yes, all right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Which contains a rack of costumes on hangars.

Dialogue.Line: Tara, Tara. Tahiti?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A grass skirt and lei.

Dialogue.Line: No. Tally ho. Tara!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mostly purple.
The Doctor opens a cupboard directly in front of the camera and removes a bunch of fake flowers and a pair of binoculars.

Dialogue.Line: What are you looking for?
Well, it's in here somewhere.
I said, what are you looking for?
Aha! Aha! Goody. Gosh, that takes me back.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: It's a fishing rod.

Dialogue.Line: Or forward. That's the trouble with time travel, you can never remember.
What is it?
Last time I used this, I was with Isaak Walton. Yes. Yes, it's all here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Romana enters in her new satin semi-cossack outfit - calf length coat over green trousers tucked into leather boots, and matching top hat with green trim. It's a Mary Tamm exclusive design.

Dialogue.Line: Well, how do you like it? Good. According to our records, it's what everyone on Tara's wearing this year. Isn't that right, K9? K9: Affirmative.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: There are sounds of the jungle, with monkeys chattering and birds of paradise calling, and the tracer clicking like crazy.

Dialogue.Line: Aha.
Aha.
Where are you going?
Fishing.
Fishing? What's fishing?
Fishing? It's an art, worthy of the knowledge and practise of a wise man. Isaak Walton
Look, we haven't got time for you to practise anything. We've got to find the fourth segment.
You find it. I'm taking the day off.
The day off?
Yes. After a journey of four hundred years and twelve parsecs, I'm allowed a rest of fifty years.
Where does it say that?
Section ninety three, paragraph two, laws governing Time Lords. You look it up. Go on.
What? You just made that up.
But you can't just spent the fifty years fishing.
Well, of course not. I'd get bored. I just propose to spend the next couple of hours fishing.
But what about the fourth segment?
You get it.
Right, I will.
Yes, you do that. It's a lovely day, beautiful countryside. The walk will do you good.
Thank you.
Would you just mind standing aside, please? You're casting a shadow. It frightens the fish.
Frightens the fish. Look, I'm going to get that fourth segment and I'll be back here in under an hour. You be ready to leave.
Yes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Romana leaves the Doctor, and crosses a small stream by some handy stepping stones. She follows the tracer signal through a well-tended piece of woodland. Something is watching here, hidden by the giant rhubarb leaves. It growls. Finally she comes to a statue near a semi-derelict mill. It is a rough image, either of Michael and the devil or George and the dragon. Same basic design - man with spear and shield standing victorious over a dead monster. Romana touches the creature's snout and it transforms into the fourth segment. That was far too easy. An ape-like creature with massive canine teeth appears out of the giant rhubarb. Romana backs away, and a man in armour comes to her rescue.

Dialogue.Line: Here, beast!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: His rapier gives off an electric charge with each hit. The creature retreats across the stream. Romana's rescuer lifts his visor to reveal himself as a man of middle years with neatly trimmed moustache and small beard.

Dialogue.Line: It's incredible!
I don't know how to thank you. If you hadn't have come along when you did, that beast would have got me. What's your name?
My name? Er, you're not damaged in any way?
No, no, I just stumbled slightly, that's all.
Your head isn't injured?
No, I don't think so. There's no harm done. I'm sorry if you're somebody frightfully important, but I'm a stranger here, you see. My name's Romana.
Ah, the fair Romana. That's a pretty name.
Thank you. Tell me, are there many creatures like that around here? I understood that the fauna of Tara were supposed to be friendly.
I always keep some beasts in my woods to hunt, but they don't usually attack people unless they're frightened in some way.
Your woods?
Yes. These are part of the estates of Gracht. What a curiously shaped stone.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He takes the fourth segment.

Dialogue.Line: Yes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Romana stumbles reaching for it.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, have you hurt your ankle?
No, no, it's nothing, really. Could I have my stone, please?
Of course, as soon as its been registered.
Registered?
Yes. Do you not know the law?
No. As I said, I'm a stranger here.
The law decrees that all minerals, particularly unusual ones like of this kind, must be registered with the Knight of Castle Gracht.
Who's that?
Me. I am Count Grendel, Knight of Gracht, Master of the Sword.
Oh, I see.
What's happened to the statue?
Is it important?
Only to superstitious fools.
Oh?
It's our family emblem. At least, it was. It's supposed to guard our fortunes. How very odd.
Look, I'm sorry, but I really must
It's of no importance. What is important is to get that ankle of your attended to.
It's nothing, really.
I shall take you to my castle. My steward can register your stone while my surgeon attends to your injury.
Look, it's very kind of you, but I really couldn't
Then I shall provide you with a mount and an escort to take you wherever you wish.
It's just a question of time.
An hour, no more. What's an hour out of your life?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Grendel picks up Romana in his arms.

Dialogue.Line: I shall not take no for an answer.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Grendel carries Romana to his steed, a white horse that is waiting patiently for him.

Dialogue.Line: What's that? Is it yours?
My favourite charger. Strong as a tree and swift as the wind.
Well, how does it go? What makes it work?
Good heavens, I don't know, my dear.
You don't?
I'm a knight, not a farrier.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is wakened by the smell of burning from his hat brim. A young knight has touched one of those electric rapiers to it.

Dialogue.Line: Do you mind not standing on my chest? My hat's on fire. I don't think we've met before.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A second older man speaks.

Dialogue.Line: Who are you?
Hmm?
Who are you?
Call me Doctor.
What are you doing here?
Oh, fishing.
This is Prince Reynart's hunting estate.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor leaps to his feet.

Dialogue.Line: What? Prince Reynart?
Yes.
I've never heard of him. Decent sort of chap, is he?
Shall I kill him, Swordmaster?
No, no, that won't be necessary.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor accidentally touches the tip of the rapier and gets a shock. He takes the weapon from the young man.

Dialogue.Line: Good heavens, electrically charged. The control's in the hilt, I see.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He hands the rapier back.

Dialogue.Line: You know about such things?
Well, I've travelled.
He said he was a doctor.
You know about machines, electronics?
A little.
You don't look like a peasant.
Well, of course not. I've travelled.
But you have certain skills. Can you mend an android?
What? What did you just say?
An android.
I thought you said an android. What's wrong with it?
It won't go.
Why don't you just try your local android dealer?
Shall I kill him now, Swordmaster?
Look, that isn't necessary. You see, I'd really love to help you out but I'm frightfully busy and where is this android?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Welcome to Leeds Castle, Kent, with a few Disney towers stuck on for effect.

Dialogue.Line: There is Castle Gracht, my dear.
It's beautiful.
It's the ancient home of the Grendels of Gracht. And it's quite, quite escape-proof, I'm glad to say.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A hunchback runs across the courtyard.

Dialogue.Line: My lord is come! Open the gate!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The big double gates swing open as Grendel and Romana ride across the moat bridge and into the courtyard. The gates swing silently closed again afterwards. Grendel lifts Romana down from the horse.

Dialogue.Line: There, that wasn't too bad, was it?
There's no need to carry me. I can still walk.
Master.
Fetch Madame Lamia.
Master.
She's my surgeon. Come, my dear.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A curious mix of old and new. A curtained Tester over an examination couch, computers and earthenware jugs, chemical retorts and a carved wooden chair. Grendel carries Romana in and lays her on the couch.

Dialogue.Line: There.
Oh, thank you. You won't forget to register my stone, will you?
What?
My stone.
Oh, no, no, of course not, my dear.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A woman enters.

Dialogue.Line: I got your message.
Oh, Romana, my dear, this is Madame Lamia, my surgeon-engineer.
Hello. Engineer?
I don't believe it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lamia examines Romana's head.

Dialogue.Line: What's the matter?
It's incredible. It's a marvellous job. Who did it?
The question is not so much who, my dear, as why.
I'm a peasant. I leave politics to my betters.
Very wise of you, my dear.
Now look, I don't know what all this is about, but I must
Restrain her.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lamia takes a box from her pocket and presses a button. Curved bars come out of the couch and over Romana's chest and ankles.

Dialogue.Line: What do you want me to do with her, my lord?
Well, we can't have her running around the kingdom. Disassemble her. We can cannibalise her for parts.
What parts? Now, wait a minute.
I should like to keep the head. You're right, it really is quite remarkable.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lamia picks up an electric carving knife.

Dialogue.Line: Ahem, you're standing on my scarf.
I'm terribly sorry.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Farrah cuts through the scarf with his rapier.

Dialogue.Line: If you don't stop burning my scarf, you're going to have to kill me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: An elegant man enters with Zadek.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor, you must forgive Swordsman Farrah. He tends to get overenthusiastic in the pursuit of his duties.
Perhaps he does
But particularly in defence of his prince.
Well, maybe he does get too enthusiastic in the course of his duty. What about my scarf?
Peasant, you will speak with respect when you address Prince Reynart of Tara.
I told you, I'm not a peasant.
But you do know about androids.
Well, that depends.
On what?
On how we treat him, obviously.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor sits, and gets another near miss with Farrah's rapier. He stands again.

Dialogue.Line: So you're not a peasant.
No.
Very well, I'll make you an offer. One thousand gold pieces if you can mend our android.
One thousand gold pieces? Pfft. Do you think you can buy me for money? Ha! Five hundred.
Done.
Suppose I can't mend the android?
Then we shall give you to Swordsman Farrah for sword practice.
No, we won't, Zadek. This man is obviously a gentleman. If he can mend our android, we shall reward him. If he cannot, you have my word, Doctor, you will come to no harm. You may go free.
Thank you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor opens the front door. There is a swordsman standing there.

Dialogue.Line: Wait. The android?
Oh yes, yes. Where? Excuse me. Reynart goes to the other side of the room and removes a blanket from a faceless android wearing similar clothes to Lamia.)
There he is, Doctor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor polishes its eyeballs.
Lamia is drawing a line across Romana's throat.

Dialogue.Line: I always enjoy watching you work, my dear.
Thank you, my lord. I shall make the cut here.
Excellent.
Count, far be it from me to query this lady's competency as a doctor, but where I come from you don't cut off the patient's head if you wish to cure their ankle!
Ankle?
Yes, there was supposed to be something wrong with its ankle.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lamia removes Romana's right boot.

Dialogue.Line: It's swollen.
Well, what did you expect?
Extraordinary. If I didn't know better, my lord.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lamia checks the back of Romana's head.

Dialogue.Line: She is not an android.
What?
She is real.
Brilliant.
Well, you can keep your head, my dear. I may have a better use for it.
That's not bad. I have seen better.
Don't you sometimes wish, Zadek, that our fathers had permitted us to learn peasant skills?
No, your highness. If we'd have meant to have been peasants, we'd have been born peasants.
Perhaps you're right, Zadek. Well, Doctor, can it be fixed?
Well, that depends. Fixed for what?
Zadek.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Zadek fetches a box.

Dialogue.Line: For one thing, it must wear this.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A Reynart face mask.

Dialogue.Line: Why?
Tomorrow, at the appropriate hour fixed by the astrologers, in the great Coronation room of the Palace of Tara, I am to be crowned King.
Well, congratulations.
They will be in order if I get there.
Why? What's to stop you?
Count Grendel of Gracht.
What?

He'll kill me if he needs to. After all, you can't crown a dead Prince. Grendel and his men will be watching every entrance to the palace to prevent my getting to the Coronation room at the ordained time.
So?
If I fail to appear at the right moment, I forfeit my right to the crown.
Ah. And that's when Grendel of Gracht steps in?
The only other contender for the throne is the Princess Strella, but she disappeared some time ago. Nobody knows where she is.
Where does George come into all this?
There have been three attempts on his Highness's life already. The next one could be successful.
Ah, I see. Let them attack George here instead of the Prince.
Precisely. We use George, the android copy of me to create a diversion, to distract their attention.
And draw their fire.
To draw their fire, while we slip past the guards into the Coronation room. What do you think, Doctor?
Well, it has been done before.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Romana sneaks the tracer out of her belt and up her right sleeve while Grendel and Lamia talk.

Dialogue.Line: I don't like it.
I'm not asking you to like it, just do it.
Is it wise? Think of the risk.
You question my commands?
No, my lord, of course not.
Then do what I tell you or I shall have you flogged, and don't imagine that I won't.
Yes, my lord.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lamia fills a hypodermic syringe while Grendel rolls up Romana's left sleeve.

Dialogue.Line: What are you doing? What? No! Please, no! Ah.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lamia injects Romana, who passes out.

Dialogue.Line: Wake up!
So much for the local wine.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Farrah has his rapier at the Doctor's throat.

Dialogue.Line: Wake up, you traitor!
What?
Traitor!
What?
I want you to be totally conscious when I kill you.
Haven't you got anything better to do?
There's only one thing preventing me from running you through right now.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Farrah drags the Doctor to his feet.

Dialogue.Line: What's that?
Where is he?
I don't know what you're talking about.
That's enough, Farrah. Doctor, the Prince has gone.
What? Where?
Vanished. He's been kidnapped.
By whom?
Your master, Count Grendel, of course!
But I don't even know who Count Grendel is!
I'm inclined to believe you, Doctor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor dashes to the curtained alcove, where the android is still lying.

Dialogue.Line: But Swordmaster
Why should he remain when the Prince has been taken? It doesn't make sense.
Well at least he didn't take the android.
They took the real Prince. What use is the copy?
Well, that depends on what you're going to do.
What honour demands.
And what's that?
Farrah and I will take our swords and do battle with the Count's men.
What? What, just the two of you?
A swordsman does not fear death if he dies with honour.
Then he's an idiot. Listen, let me see if I understand this. In order to be crowned King, the Prince must present himself in the Coronation room at a specific time, right?
Correct.
Then you've got no problem. Excuse me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor sits in the Prince's chair.

Dialogue.Line: You take it to the Coronation room and get it crowned.
Crown an android King of Tara? Never!
Would you rather crown Count Grendel of Gracht?
But an android. It's unthinkable.
In any case, Grendel's men will see that we don't get into the Coronation room.
Well, I don't suppose the King was going to walk in through the front door, was he?
He had a plan.
Ah. What?
There is a secret passage.
Aha, I thought there might be something like that. How secret? Would Grendel know about it?
I hope not.

So do I. Right, now listen. I'll do some more work on George, you get him to the Coronation room, get him crowned, and while he's ruling the country you two can find the real Prince. I mean, that's worth a try, isn't it?
Doctor, I see only two objections to your plan.
Only two?
What if the android breaks down?
Ah, well, I can't guarantee you anything, but if I had the proper tools
Second problem, security.
Security? But only the three of us need even know of George's existence.
Precisely. Farrah I can trust.
And by the time George is King, I'll be light years away.
No, Doctor. You'll be with the android at all times.
Now look here, Zadek. I've got better things to do than meddle in the politics of your piffling little planet.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Farrah puts his electric rapier close to the Doctor's face.

Dialogue.Line: On the other hand, I could be with the android at all times.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor blows K9's dog whistle, and the mobile computer wakes up in the Tardis.

Dialogue.Line: What are you doing?
Calling my dog.
I don't see any dog.
Well, of course not. He hasn't arrived yet.
Master.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is sewing up the back of George's wig.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor? You've checked the android?
Well, as far as I can without the proper tools.
Everything is functioning correctly?
No. His micro-circuitry's not perfect and his power packs need a boost.
I have great confidence in you, Doctor.
I'm deeply touched.
But remember, either Farrah or myself will be with you at all times. Don't let us down.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A bird screeches outside. Farrah and the Doctor go to the window.

Dialogue.Line: Don't draw that sword.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor opens the door and K9 trundles in.

Dialogue.Line: You called, master?
What is that thing?
That thing? That's my dog.
But it's a machine.
Well, so is your Prince.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor kicks the chair the android is sitting on, and Farrah reacts.

Dialogue.Line: Don't draw that sword!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Farrah's hand and rapier are caught in an energy field.
The energy field stops and Farrah drops the rapier. The Doctor picks it up.

Dialogue.Line: Look, I don't like to say I told you so, but I told you so. Do put it away, quickly. K9, where's Romana? K9: She has not yet returned, master.
What? Where is she? K9: Insufficient data to formulate a reply. She's not within range of my sensors.
But she was only meant to be gone an hour.
You've lost someone?
Yes, my assistant. She was looking for something.
What?
Oh, nothing important.
Where was she last seen?
Where you picked me up yesterday.
Which way was she going?
Up the hill.
Towards Count Grendel's lands.
I'm afraid, Doctor, that it sounds as though she might have fallen into the hands of the Count.
So, the lovely lady wakes.
How long have I been unconscious?
Twelve hours, my dear. I trust you slept well. Release her.
Twelve hours? Oh, no.
Why, what's the matter, my dear?
Look, why don't you just let me go? I've no money and I'm not worth ransoming. Why did you bring me here?
Do you think I'm a common bandit?
I'm not even Taran. What possible use can I be to you?
I'll show you. Help her down.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lamia helps Romana get off the couch.

Dialogue.Line: Come with me. I want you to see something.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Grendel leads Romana and Lamia down steps to a dark vaulted area, where a guard stands by a door.

Dialogue.Line: And how is our guest?
She's well, my lord.
Good. Let's see for ourselves.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Grendel slides open a panel in the door.

Dialogue.Line: Take a look, my dear.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Romana looks into the cell.

Dialogue.Line: Oh! It's incredible!
Yes, the resemblance is extraordinary, isn't it?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: In the cell, an exact double of Romana is sitting sewing a tapestry.

Dialogue.Line: Is it an android?

Good heavens, no, my dear. That's the Princess Strella. First Lady of Tara, a descendant of the Royal House, Mistress of the domains of Thorvald, Mortgarde and Freya. In fact, Tara's most eligible spinster, shortly to become, in rapid succession, my fiancée, my bride, and then deceased. Yes, it will be a tragic accident. A flower blighted in its prime. And naturally, as her husband, I shall claim her estates and her position as second in line to the throne, as provided for under Taran law.
I see. But since you've already got a princess, what do you need me for?
Well, the Princess does not entirely agree with my plan.
I can't say I'm wildly surprised.
In fact, she quite refuses to cooperate.
Good for her. But I still don't see what all this has got to do with me.
Don't you, my dear? I should have thought that was obvious. If she goes on refusing, I can marry you instead in front of the great assembly of the nobles of Tara, who won't know the difference.
What happens if I refuse, too?
Oh, but you won't. Aren't I a lucky man to have two such beautiful women as my bride?
Apparently your staff doesn't agree.
She's prejudiced, my dear, just because I once showed her a certain courtesy. That's the trouble with peasants these days. They don't know their place any more. Open!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Grendel enters a second cell in his dungeons. Prince Reynart is lying on a cot with a metal shackle around his neck, chained to the wall.

Dialogue.Line: Why don't you kill me, Grendel, and get it over with.
Never rush your pleasures, my dear Reynart. Besides, I've brought someone to see you. Meet his Royal Highness, Prince Reynart, first in line to the throne of Tara.
Strella!
No, I'm not Strella. I just look like her. My name's Romana.
You see, my dear Reynart, when I play for high stakes I like to hold all the cards.
You won't be holding this one much longer. He's ill. He's running a fever.
That's why we brought him a permanent nurse for his bedside. Hold her, Kurster. Lamia.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Grendel's equivalent of Zadek grabs Romana while Lamia puts a shackle around Romana's neck.

Dialogue.Line: Let her go!
Don't be so tediously heroic, my dear fellow. Not too tight, Lamia. We don't want to choke her.
She is secure, my lord.
Good.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kurster fastens Romana's chain to the wall.

Dialogue.Line: You know, my dear Reynart, you ought to thank me.
For what?
For what? For finding you such a charming nurse. There. Take good care of our royal guest, my dear. Watch them, Kurster.
Yes, my lord.
And now, my friend, I must go to your coronation. It's a pity you will miss it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A map is on the table.

Dialogue.Line: Where is Count Grendel's castle?
About eight leagues from here.
Eight leagues.
You're not thinking of going there alone?
Well, where else might he have taken her if not there?
To Tara itself. He will want to make sure that no one else claims the throne.
Right. K9, you take the castle. I'll go to Tara with George.
You're going to help us then?
Well, of course. Anyway, we need Zadek to get us into the palace, right?
Correct, Doctor.
K9, off you go. Find out if Romana's there and report straight back to me. Come on, off you go.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor shoos K9 out of the door.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor?
What?
Is he a good hunting dog?
Oh, well, if she's there, he'll find her.
There's not a lot of time left.
We're almost there. Wait here. I'll go ahead and scout.
Good.
Be careful, Swordmaster. He's not as young as he used to be.
Who is.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Farrah talks to George.

Dialogue.Line: Are you all right, sir? How do you feel? (no reply) I can't talk to androids. Is he all right?
Yes, I think so.
He's not talking.
Well, I've switched off his communication mechanism to conserve power.
He'll have to make a speech at his coronation.
Don't worry, he'll make a speech. Don't worry. It won't be a long one, but he'll make a speech.
I don't know what it is about androids. I know it's silly. You know what I mean.
Funny thing, some androids feel like that about humans.
I have found the place. Come.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: There is a guard with a crossbow patrolling up and down.

Dialogue.Line: It's one of Grendel's men.
I'll deal with him.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Farrah circles round, then throws a rock to misdirect the guard. He zaps him with his rapier when the guard turns back again.

Dialogue.Line: Will he recover?
In a few hours.
Good.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor picks up the crossbow.

Dialogue.Line: It fires electronic bolts. How very quaint.
It's a peasant's weapon.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor puts it down again.

Dialogue.Line: Come, there's no time to lose.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: While K9 watches guards patrolling the battlements, Lamia is working on an android's head. She pauses to examine the Key segment.

Dialogue.Line: That's curious.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She tries drilling it, but makes no mark.

Dialogue.Line: That's very odd.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: K9 has located where Romana is being held.

Dialogue.Line: Mistress?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Romana cleans a wound on Reynart's right arm.

Dialogue.Line: So you're a friend of the Doctor?
Yes. Don't worry, he'll get us out of here.
Huh. How? No one's ever escaped from the dungeons of Castle Gracht. Ow. How is it? Not good, eh?
Look, don't try and talk. Just conserve your strength.
For what? I can't swim the moat with this, let alone take on the guard.
The Doctor'll find a way.
Soon, I hope. I'd like to try and avoid giving Grendel the pleasure of dying in one of his foul dungeons.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Two guards burst in, and one starts to unfasten Romana's collar.

Dialogue.Line: Peasants! How dare you lay hands on a lady.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Romana is taken out of the cell.

Dialogue.Line: What were these tunnels built for?
They were plague tunnels built about two hundred years ago to allow the royal court to move in and out of the palace without having to pass through the contaminated city.
Ah.
The great plague wiped out nine tenths of the population.
That's when the survivors started using androids to replace the people.
I see. Very far yet?
Quite a way, I fear.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A troop of Grendel's guards find their fallen comrade at the secret entrance, and go into the tunnels.

The sole hand on the zodiac clock moves from Aquarius back to Capricorn. Taran nobility is gathered here when some of Grendel's men enter and go to the door to the main hall. Kurster speaks to the royal guards.

Dialogue.Line: You're relieved of your post. Go.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The royal guard commander nods, and the guards leave.

Dialogue.Line: Take up your place. Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Grendel's men take over security. Count Grendel enters the Coronation Room, lit with stained glass windows, and mounts the steps to the golden throne. He sits, laughs, and leaves. The pursuit continues through the tunnels. The clock hand moves from Sagittarius to Scorpio. Kurster enters and salutes Grendel.

Dialogue.Line: Well?
Everything is ready, my lord.
The peasants are prepared?

I have my men dressed as peasants, my lord. As soon as it is announced that the Prince has not appeared for the coronation, there will be a spontaneous demonstration of love and loyalty to the House of Gracht.
I think I shall reject the crown once. Rejecting it twice might be misconstrued. Besides, I'm not sure I can trust the Archimandrite to offer it to me a third time.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Archimandrite enters from the Coronation Room. He is a small but dignified figure with a neat silver beard and multicoloured turban, who has the role of the Archbishop of Canterbury in these matters.

Dialogue.Line: The hour approaches, Count Grendel.
It does indeed, your Eminence.
Where is the Prince?
No doubt he will be here, your Eminence.
If he misses the appointed hour of his coronation, we must choose another king. That is the law.
I know.
It is possible we may choose you.
You overwhelm me, your Eminence.
We're nearly there. The steps to the Coronation chamber are just round the corner.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: George bumps into a stone hanging down from the roof of the tunnel.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor!
What? Stop him!
Is he going to be all right?
Let's hope so. Off you go.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They move forward into weapons fire from behind them bouncing off the walls. The Doctor steers George to one side.

Dialogue.Line: Look out!
We've been followed! Doctor, take the Prince. We'll try to hold them off here. There's a lever at the top. Pull it down. It opens a panel. Hurry!
It can't have been moved for two hundred years. It's stuck! It won't move.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The clock hand moves to the line between Aries and Pisces, nearly straight up now. The Archimandrite reenters.

Dialogue.Line: There's no sign of the Prince, Count Grendel.
He would appear to be late, your Eminence.
If he doesn't appear by the appointed time, it is my duty under the law to offer the crown to one of the other nobles.
My dear Archimandrite, you may rest assured that whoever you choose to be King of Tara will immediately be offered the protection of my guard.
Your guard? These are your men?
Er, the palace guard proved to be indisposed.
I see. Perhaps, in the circumstances, it would be simpler if I offered you the crown immediately.
An excellent suggestion, my dear Archimandrite. It would avoid a great deal of possible unpleasantness later. But we must wait for the exact moment. Everything must be done correctly.
Noble sentiments, Count. Nobly spoken.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The clock strikes. The hand is straight up.

Dialogue.Line: Look, it is time. It is time! Open the doors. (To a fanfare, the Archimandrite leads Grendel and the other nobles into -
Are you mad?
Seize him! He's killed the Princess.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Princess's wig has come off with the sceptre to reveal a big hole in a smooth pink cranium.

Dialogue.Line: Stop! That's not the Princess.
It's an android.
How did you know?
A circuit must have been faulty. I heard it spark.
And who might you be, pray?
But it doesn't make sense. Why send an android to swear loyalty to the King?
To get close enough to kill him.
But who would want to kill the King?
Ah.
Unless
My dear Archimandrite, what are you suggesting?
Treachery against His Majesty.
Take care what you say, Zadek. Your Eminence, I suggest we postpone the oath-taking for the time being. Who knows how many other programmed androids there may be.
You think there are more?
It is a possibility we must face, your Eminence. I shall leave my own personal guard here to protect His Majesty.
I'm afraid I cannot permit that, Count.
It is not for you to say.
As Commander of His Majesty's bodyguard, it is my decision and mine alone.
You presume too much, Zadek. Well, what does His Majesty have to say on the matter? He is very quiet.
Ahem. His Majesty is very tired. Can't you talk about this tomorrow?
Who the devil are you, sir?
I'm the King's Doctor.
Is His Majesty ill?
No, nothing a nice rest won't cure. He'll be all right tomorrow.
I understand, Doctor. Come, Count. We must allow His Majesty to rest.
But what of the danger?
What possible danger can His Majesty be in from his own personal bodyguard, Count?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Archimandrite and Grendel leave, but the guards stay.

Dialogue.Line: Will he be all right tomorrow?
Not unless I can recharge his power packs and repair his speech circuits.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lamia is still trying to get a sample off the Key Segment when a guard pushes Romana inside the room.

Dialogue.Line: Is this yours?
Yes.
What is it?
What is it?
Yes. What is it made of?
Oh, I've no idea. I only found it the other day.
It's like no substance I have ever seen before. I have blunted two diamond drills on it.
Well, perhaps it's some kind of quartz?
This is no quartz.
Well, if you don't want it, could I have it back? You've no use for it, have you?
I don't suppose it matters. What could you possibly do with it? No.
Why not?
I'm curious. It looks as though it might be part of something.
Part of what?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Grendel bursts in, followed by Till the hunchback.

Dialogue.Line: It failed. The machine failed. That doctor saw at once it was an android.
My lord, I did warn you it wasn't ready.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Till takes Grendel's cloak.

Dialogue.Line: What doctor?
Oh, some strange doctor who's attending the Prince.
We hold the real Prince. What you have seen must have been an android.
Obviously. Do you know this doctor?
No.
I think you do. Lamia, prepare another android. An exact copy precise to the last detail. I have an idea. Our guest can help us.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor has the back of George's head open. K9 enters.

Dialogue.Line: Master.
K9. K9: I have located the mistress. She is in Castle Gracht.
Are you sure? K9: Affirmative, master. I detected her presence quite distinctly.
Good. Well, that means the Count has Romana, the real Princess and the Prince.
So Grendel now holds all the cards.
No, I wouldn't say that. We've still got a prince of sorts.
He has to attend the convocation with the Archimandrite and the priests. Will he be able to?
Well, K9, what would happen if I connect the carbon circuit to the silicon circuit? How long would they last?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: K9 rolls up to George and sticks out his detector.

Dialogue.Line: Come on. K9: Three hours nine minutes and ten point seven seconds, approximately.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Romana has been strapped down on the couch again, with a metal circlet around her forehead. A computer bank is whirring.

Dialogue.Line: Comfortable, my dear?
My lord?
What is it?
These are like no alpha waves I have ever seen before.
What do you mean?
She is not Taran.
Then what is she?
I don't know. I need more time for evaluation.
Time we don't have, my dear. Just programme another android to kill, that's all, but this time make sure it's a perfect copy.
Yes, my lord.
Go on, ask him a question. Go on.
The question of monastic lands. That's bound to come up at the convocation. What is His Majesty's position on that?
Monastic lands are held by the religious orders under the protection of the Crown. Those lands and that protection may be withdrawn at my discretion at any time.
Good.
I propose to be discreet for the time being.
Yes. Doctor, the Prince
King.
Oh, quite so, your Majesty.
Zadek.
Oh, drat. I keep forgetting he's only an android. Doctor, the King seems to be, how shall I say, a trifle more
Intelligent than the real one? Well, of course he is. I programmed him.
We don't want him too intelligent, Doctor. You can't trust androids, you know.
It's funny, you know. That's what some androids say about people.
What?
Anyway, how can you possibly be frightened of something that goes pfft if it short-circuits?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Farrah enters.

Dialogue.Line: Someone to speak to the Doctor, sir.
Who?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Count's hunchback enters.

Dialogue.Line: Ah.
My name is Till. I am but a servant to the Count.
And what do you want?
My mission is with the doctor, Swordsman, not with thee.
You dare to refuse to speak to a Master of the Sword?
Swordsman, I will speak only to the doctor. Those are my orders.
Quite right, too. Quite right. We peasants have got to stick together. Now then, what can I do for you, huh?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor leads Till away from the group.

Dialogue.Line: I have a message from Madame Lamia.
Lamia?
Yeah, she's Count Grendel's woman, a peasant.
Well?
She would have me tell you that she fears for the Count's safety.
Why?
Now they've crowned the android King, the Count is politically powerless.
Shush. Come over here.
I suppose he can be trusted?
Who, the servant or the Doctor?
The Doctor, of course. (to Zadek) He can be trusted, can't he, sir?
I wish we knew more about him.
There's only one way to settle this. K9: Do not activate your sword.
Good dog. Good dog.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor returns to the group.

Dialogue.Line: Lamia's offered us a deal.
What?
Romana in exchange for the safe conduct out of the country of Count Grendel.
You refused, of course.
No, no, I accepted. I'm to take a written undertaking from you and the King for Grendel's safety, then Lamia and her friends will pass Romana over to me.
It's an obvious trap. You can't go.
Yes, I can.
Where is the meeting to take place?
At a place called the Pavilion of the Summer Winds. Do you know where it is?
Yes. It's on Grendel's estate, in the woods near the castle.
Good. I shall have to go alone, of course. It's funny, they always want you to go alone when you're walking into a trap. Have you noticed that?
You've excelled yourself, my dear Lamia. It's absolutely perfect. Don't you agree?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Romana glares at her android duplicate.

Dialogue.Line: The Doctor'll spot it immediately.
In the dark at a distance of twenty feet? I think not, my dear.
He'll know it's a trap.
Of course! That's what gives the situation such a delicious edge.
He won't come.

You underestimate your friend, my dear. Of course he'll come. What else could he do? It's his only chance of rescuing you. Oh, he'll be very careful, very cautious. He'll bide his time. But sooner or later he must find out if that figure in the Pavilion is you or not. And when he does. Show her, Lamia.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lamia wheels a chair in front of the wall and uncovers a tailor's dummy. Then she picks up a control.

Dialogue.Line: Hello, Romana. How are you?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Romana 2 steps forward and a bolt of energy zaps from her waist into the dummy's chest.

Dialogue.Line: Rather ingenious, don't you think? You are to be congratulated, my dear.
How did you get the voice?
The Count's man, Till, recorded his voice patterns when they parleyed. Once I have the pattern, the construction of speech is a simple matter.
It won't work.
Why not?
Well, supposing the Doctor doesn't speak?
The android is also programmed to kill in various other ways.
You see before you the complete killing machine, as beautiful as you and as deadly as the plague. If only she were real, I'd marry her.
You deserve each other.
Come, my dear.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Romana 2 takes Grendel's proffered arm and they leave. Lamia goes to the door and Romana takes a small metal pick from an instrument box.

Dialogue.Line: Guard! Guard!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lamia turns back and a guard enters.

Dialogue.Line: What kept you so long? Bring this one back to the cells.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Reynart is still sweating with his fever.

Dialogue.Line: Leave us. I will lock up the prisoner.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The guard leaves and Lamia puts the neck shackle on Romana.

Dialogue.Line: You know, if Grendel does become king, he'll never make you his queen.
Nor you, either. I will see to that.
Ah, but I don't want him and you do, don't you. Look, why don't you let me go? All you have to do is release me and the Doctor, and I'll leave Tara. Think about it. What have you got to lose?
Grendel.
Well, you haven't exactly got him now, have you? All he's doing is using you.
I know. But that is better than nothing.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lamia leaves. Romana takes the pick from her belt and starts to work on her collar.

Dialogue.Line: Now, how does the Doctor do this?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Just to be awkward, the actual Pavilion at Leeds Castle was used as the Hunting Lodge. This pretty hexagonal building is nearby, across the lawn and on the other side of the pathway. The Doctor and K9 hide in the long grass. The birds are doing a lot of singing.

Dialogue.Line: Shush. Steady, K9, steady. Let's take a look.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Romana has unpicked her collar, and is working on Reynart's when he wakes.

Dialogue.Line: Shush. We're getting out of here.
Save yourself.
And leave you behind? They'll kill you.
I'm, I'm too weak. I'd only get in the way.
Listen, Grendel's taken most of the guards with him. Now's our chance.
Then take it. Don't waste time with me. Tell Zadek where I am. He'll know what to do.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and K9 enter the Pavilion quietly. Romana has freed Reynart from his collar. She helps him wraps it and the chain around his hand.

Dialogue.Line: That's it.
Okay.
Like that. Good. Ready?
Go ahead.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Romana goes to the door as Reynart starts crying out in pain.

Dialogue.Line: Guard! Guard! Guard, quickly! The Prince!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The guard rushes in and goes straight to Reynart. Romana slips out as Reynart hits the guard with his improvised knuckleduster.

Dialogue.Line: My lord. The men are in position, my lord.
Good. Await my signal. Tell them to be ready.
Yes, sir.
You know what to do, my dear.
Yes. When this Doctor arrives, you leave him to me.
What should I do without you?
Find another peasant who understands androids, no doubt.
True, but I should not find one who pleased me so much.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Grendel kisses Lamia.

Dialogue.Line: Go now, before he arrives.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lamia snaps her fingers, and the Romana android follows her.

Meanwhile, Romana has got as far as the castle courtyard, where Grendel's white horse stands waiting for a rider. The guard at the far end of the gateway is leaning on his crossbow looking outwards. Romana uses the wrong foot in the stirrup to mount the patient horse, and shuffles herself round whilst looking for the start button.

Dialogue.Line: Go, Charger. Start. Start! Go, you stupid creature, go!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She finally kicks the horse into action as another guard turns and fires his crossbow. The horse canters through the castle entrance and away.
Lamia enters, looks around and is about to leave again when the Doctor slams the door in her face.

Dialogue.Line: Hello. You're early.
Doctor?
Yes. Madame Lamia, is it?
We agreed to meet at midnight.
Yes, but I had nothing better to do so I thought I'd come early. What's your reason?
Do I need one?
No, but it would have been fun to hear it. Where's Romana?
You agree to my terms?
I do indeed. Safe conduct for Count Grendel in return for Romana, also safe and sound.
Yes.
Where is Romana? You realise, of course, that Count Grendel will have to go into exile, but there's no reason then why you can't go into exile with him, is there? Where's Romana?
Outside.
You bring her in. It's a good offer, Lamia. A fair offer.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor opens the door and Lamia leaves. He shuts it again. Outside, Lamia smiles at Grendel and leads the android in. She holds out her hand and the Doctor throws a small scroll to her.

Dialogue.Line: Well, Doctor, aren't you going to greet your friend? K9: Caution, master.
What is it, K9?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The android's energy beam goes over the Doctor's head as he stoops to talk to K9.

Dialogue.Line: Kill him! Kill him! Kill him!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lamia has to steer the android around the central post to get a line on the Doctor, who is now by the door and opposite K9.

Dialogue.Line: In focus, K9? K9: Affirmative.
Now!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: K9 shoots the android three times in the back. Lamia screams.

Dialogue.Line: Something's gone wrong. Attack the Pavilion!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A troop of guards start firing their crossbows at the building. Lamia comes running out.

Dialogue.Line: My lord! My lord!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: And gets shot.

Dialogue.Line: You fools! That was Madame Lamia! Hold your fire!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lamia sinks to the ground.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor, I know you're in there. There's only one entrance to that pavilion. Come out, Doctor. Surrender. We won't harm you. (to Kurster) Tell the bowmen to fire immediately they see the target. I want him destroyed. Well, Doctor? Are you coming out? You have my word as a Gracht you will not be harmed.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The bowmen take aim from the shrubbery.

Dialogue.Line: Ill-advised, master.
What? You just leave it to me, K9. I know exactly what I'm doing.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor walks outside and the bowmen start shooting. He dashes back inside again, then opens the door to shout at Grendel.

Dialogue.Line: Liar!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He shuts the door against the fusillade of electronic bolts.

Dialogue.Line: It's time we got out of here, isn't it, K9. K9: Affirmative, master.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor points to a part of the wall at the back of the pavilion.

Dialogue.Line: Around here, do you think? K9: Affirmative.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor directs K9 as he uses his laser to cut an arc through the wall, then punches it out.

Dialogue.Line: Come on!
There he is! He's got out!
Ten thousand gold pieces to the man who shoots the Doctor!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor dodges out of sight through the trees.

Dialogue.Line: Wait. Listen.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Romana comes galloping up on Grendel's horse.

Dialogue.Line: The Princess! Hold your fire!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Romana catches up with the Doctor.

Dialogue.Line: Everyone for himself, K9!
Fools! Dolts! That wasn't the Princess, it was Romana! After them!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: K9 cuts down the pursuing guards. Grendel puts his head in his hands in frustration. The Doctor has mounted the horse behind Romana and they are galloping away.

Dialogue.Line: I hope you know how to stop this thing when we get there.
While Grendel still thinks we're in the Palace, we may be able to surprise him. You must bring up a troop of bowmen under cover of darkness and position them on the left flank, here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Romana enter.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor!
It's the Princess!
No, I'm Romana.
Incredible.
Isn't it?
Ah, this must be the android King.
Yes. We call him George.
And these gentlemen?
Oh, they're real, I think.
This is Swordsman Farrah. I am Swordmaster Zadek.
Zadek? I have a message for you from the real king.
You've seen His Majesty? How is he?
He's not very well. We must think of a plan to rescue him.
(at the door) Horseman approaching.
(looking through the window) Under a flag of truce. It's Count Grendel! I'll kill the traitor!
Not if he comes under a flag of truce. You know the articles of war, Swordsman.
I'm not sure Count Grendel does, sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Romana hide in an inner room.

Dialogue.Line: Disarm the Count, then, and bring him in.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Farrah and a guard escort Grendel in, carrying a spear with a white cloth tied to it.

Dialogue.Line: Good day, gentlemen. I come to you under a flag of truce and expect to be treated according to the usages of war.
What do you want?
How are you, your android Majesty?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: George speaks very slowly.

Dialogue.Line: I. Am. Well.
He doesn't sound it. Power packs need recharging, I expect.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor opens the inner door.

Dialogue.Line: Nothing that can't be fixed, Count.
Oh, Doctor! Well, there you are. I was glad you managed to escape safely.
Yes, well, so was I.
Tell me now, where is the charming Romana?
What do you want, Count Grendel?
Only a word with the Doctor, according to the usages of war.
Me?
Shall we?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor leads Grendel into the curtained alcove.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, excellent.
Well?
Oh, Doctor, you're a remarkable man.
I am?
Yes, a man after my own heart.
I am?
Here you are, new to Taran politics, and in no time at all what have you become?
I don't know. Go on, you tell me.

Kingmaker extraordinary. Thanks to you keeping that micro-circuitry going, Zadek has his king. But have you thought what would happen if something went seriously wrong, like an overload on the circuits?
What would happen?
Your usefulness ceases.
What?
You know too much. You become a dangerous embarrassment to Zadek. An embarrassment to be got rid of, and don't think he wouldn't.
What's the answer?
Suppose we both unmade our kings. No more King Reynart at all.
What? What would that achieve?
A vacancy for a new king.
Ah. You, I suppose?
No, no, no, Doctor, no. There would be opposition. No, I was thinking you'd make an excellent king.
Me? Just a moment.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor goes over to Zadek.

Dialogue.Line: The Count's just offered me the throne.
That's treason, Count.
Only so long as the King is alive!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Grendel throws his spear into George, who goes bang!, then dashes for the inner door.

Dialogue.Line: Seize him!
Commander, take six men, mount up and follow the Count.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The guard commander leaves.

Dialogue.Line: He'll be halfway to Castle Gracht by now.
You know, you almost have to admire the man.
Admire him? I should have killed him when he walked in here, flag of truce or no flag of truce.
You've got to admit, sir, it takes courage to walk in here, to distract our attention while his men kidnap Miss Romana. I mean, it takes nerve.
Nerve is one quality Grendel has never been short of.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Reynart has been reshackled to the wall.

Dialogue.Line: Romana!
Are you all right?
I thought you'd escaped.
She had, but I knew Your Majesty couldn't live without her, so I brought her back for you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kurster shackles Romana.

Dialogue.Line: Why do you torment him?
Oh, now that's really most unfair, my dear. I'm really quite hurt. All I'm doing is to restore to His Majesty his bride-to-be.
What?
You'll make a lovely couple.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Grendel and Kurster leave.

Dialogue.Line: What's his idea? Is it a joke?
Oh, no. Grendel doesn't joke about political power.
Then what's his plan?
To become legal, rightful King of Tara. You see, if you marry me you will automatically become Queen, but five minutes after the wedding you would almost certainly be a widow.
He'd kill you?
He would. And the moment you're widowed, Count Grendel, that well- known champion of widows and orphans, would step in and marry you, thus becoming Consort of the rightful Queen of Tara.
And then it would be my turn for an unfortunate accident.
Precisely.
This is not wine, but vinegar. Fetch good wine, dog!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Till hurries out. A guard shows the Archimandrite in.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, Archimandrite. Welcome.
What is so urgent that I must leave my duties and hurry here like this?
I'm sorry, Archimandrite, but there is a ceremony you must perform.
Here? What ceremony?
A marriage.
Your own chaplain could have done that.
Not this marriage.
Why? Who is to be married, and to whom?
The King to the Princess Strella.
The King? Here?
He has placed himself under my protection, your Eminence. Sadly, I have to tell you he is sick. In fact, he's very near to death.
Oh, dear, dear, dear. He did not look well at the coronation. Not himself at all.
No. No, I did note that, Archimandrite.
But near to death, you say?
Indeed he is. It would be as well if you stayed here. I fear he will be in need of the funeral rites very soon after the wedding.
Oh, how sad.
Mmm, yes. And after the funeral rites, there will be a second wedding for you to perform.
A second wedding? May I ask whose that will be?
My own. I shall be marrying the poor King's widow.
But surely, sir, we have a supply problem if we place the batteries there.
But if we do what you're suggesting, we expose our left flank.
How long do you think the siege will last, Zadek?
Hard to say. The last siege of the Castle of Gracht went on for nearly two years.
Two years? Well, we haven't got two years before Grendel kills both the King and Romana. Anyway, looking at that plan, I'd say there's only one way into the castle.
What's that?
If someone on the inside opens the main gate and a group of our men, under cover of darkness, take the guard by surprise.
That's hardly ethical.
Have you ever known Grendel abide by the rules of war? But who's going to open the gates?
Me.
One man alone?
No, no. One man and his dog. Come on, K9.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Grendel checks first on Romana and Reynart, then goes to Strella's cell.

Dialogue.Line: Open.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She is, of course, working on the tapestry.

Dialogue.Line: Your Highness.
Grendel.
I have come to offer you one last chance to change your mind.
Never.
The Archimandrite is here, the King is here. It will be quite easy for you.
Grendel, I've told you already. I will never marry you under any circumstances, and I will not marry the King under these circumstances.
Come, come, my dear. Don't you want to be Queen?
I know, Grendel, that as long as I refuse to marry the King, his life is safe.
Huh. And that matters to you?
More than my own life. For the last time, I will not go through any marriage under your roof. You can kill me if you like.
Very well, my dear, I may just do that before long. You have become dispensable, Princess.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Grendel clicks his heels and leaves.
He goes along to the second cell.

Dialogue.Line: Open.
How is he?
Very weak.
Oh, what a shame. I fear he's not long for this world.
Nonsense. All he needs is some proper medical
I know exactly what he needs, my dear. Just as long as he's the strength left for a little ceremony.
Never. Do you hear me, Grendel? Never.
Oh, what a pity, because I'm sure you wouldn't want to be the cause of Princess Strella's death, would you?
What do you mean?
Or you, my dear.
What are you saying?
The Princess, the real Princess, that is, is in the next dungeon. For the moment she's quite safe.
If you harm her, Grendel

What! What can you do? Be quiet and listen to me. I had everything arranged before this girl and her friend interfered. Madame Lamia was preparing a perfect android copy of the Princess for you to marry. You would have been married with full ceremony, and after your unfortunate death at her hands, she would have married me. Now Madame Lamia is dead and the android can never be completed. So, we need another bride.
Well, if you think you can persuade me to marry anybody, you're wrong.
Oh, but I do. I'm sure you will. Because if you refuse, the Princess will die. Very slowly. Now what have you to say? Good. I thought you'd see reason. I shall return shortly. Be ready.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Nighttime. The waters of the moat glint in the moonlight. An owl hoots nearby. The Doctor and K9 are in a small boat.

Dialogue.Line: All right, K9, let's go.
The old watergate should be right under the far wall.
Good.
I'm afraid the door must be a foot thick. The timbers were intended to withstand any battering ram.
Don't worry.
But
Don't worry, we'll manage. You just make sure you're all ready to charge in the moment those gates are open.
Doctor.
Yes?
Take this. You may need it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Farrah offers his rapier.

Dialogue.Line: Too complicated for me.
We'll be waiting, Doctor.
Good.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor pushes off with the oar.

Dialogue.Line: Good luck.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Sentries patrol the battlements to the music of frogs and owls. The Doctor paddles the boat under an archway to a door in the castle walls.
Grendel enters.

Dialogue.Line: Is everything ready?
Almost, master.
There must be no hitches in any of the ceremonies tonight.
No, master.
Kurster, a word.
My lord.
Make sure our guards are alert. You yourself watch everything. At the first sign of trouble, get down to the dungeons and deal with the Princess. You understand me?
I do, my lord.
I shall deal with the King myself.
I shall be nearby if you need help.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A guard admits the Archimandrite.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, Archimandrite. Are you ready?
I am. Where are the happy couple? They are in their quarters. I shall inform them we are ready and conduct them here myself.
Here we are, K9. Here we are. This must be it. K9: Affirmative, master. This is the position marked on the plan.
Shush. Quiet. Just start cutting.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: K9 begins lasering the wood as they continue to drift forward.

Dialogue.Line: Open.
Kurster.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Romana and Reynart have been dressing in wedding finery. Kurster unshackles Romana first.

Dialogue.Line: Well, why so miserable? This should be the happiest day of your life. It will also be your last, so you might as well enjoy it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Reynart tries to hit Grendel, and Kurster pushes him back onto the cot.

Dialogue.Line: Remember, no trouble or the Princess dies. That I promise.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A peal of bells sounds out.

Dialogue.Line: Hear that, K9? Wedding bells or a funeral knell? Do hurry up. A hamster with a blunt penknife would do it quicker. K9: You ordered me to make no noise, master.
Just get on with it.
Cheer up, it'll all be over soon. I'm sorry there's no bridal march, my dear. Guard!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A guard opens the door.

Dialogue.Line: After you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Grendel follows Romana and Reynart out of the dungeons.

Dialogue.Line: About time, too.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor knocks the cut panel out of the door.

Dialogue.Line: Good.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He clambers out of the boat.

Dialogue.Line: You all right? Now listen, there's bound to be lots of stairs in there. You stay here and keep an eye on the boat. I might have to bring the others out this way if anything goes wrong. K9: Affirmative, master.
And don't fall in the water. K9: I am familiar with boats, master.
You old sea dog, you. Now don't forget, stand guard and be careful. Be careful!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor disappears from sight, and trips over something with a crash and yell.

Dialogue.Line: Master?
Shush!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Romana and Reynart enter. The peal stops.

Dialogue.Line: Both kneel.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Reynart and Romana look at each other.

Dialogue.Line: Remember the Princess.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They kneel. Meanwhile, the Doctor takes the Key Segment from Lamia's laboratory.

Dialogue.Line: Do you, Reynart, King of Tara, take this woman, the Princess Strella, to be your lawful wedded wife? (silence) Your Majesty?
I do.
And do you, Strella, Princess of the Royal House of Tara, take this man, Reynart, King of Tara, to be your lawful wedded husband?
No!
Doctor!

No, she doesn't. Hello, everyone. Sorry I'm late. If there's something I always enjoy, it's a good wedding, isn't that true, Romana? (to the Archimandrite) Now, listen. Have you got to the bit where you ask them if there's any just cause why they shouldn't be joined in
You seem to make a habit of interfering in my affairs, Doctor.
Yes, yes, I do really.
Well, you've done it for the last time.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Grendel draws his sword. Till hits the Doctor in the stomach, doubling him over.

Dialogue.Line: Stop! This is a solemn ceremony!
Not any more, it isn't.
Stop!
Leave him, leave him. he's mine. Defend yourself, sir.
I haven't brought my sword.
Well, I've no wish to kill a man without a weapon in his hand. Here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Grendel throws his own sword to the Doctor.

Dialogue.Line: Till!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Till goes to get another sword from the display over the fireplace. Romana goes over to the Doctor.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor, he's the best swordsman on Tara.
Is he?
Do you know what you're doing? Good luck.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Grendel has put on his helmet.

Dialogue.Line: I shall give you a fencing lesson before you die.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They salute each other. The Doctor's rapier hits a stone column and sparks. Grendel takes the en garde position and the Doctor copies him exactly, turning his back to his opponent.

Dialogue.Line: En garde!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Grendel hits the Doctor in the back. The Doctor turns and the fight begins. Grendel makes the attacks and the Doctor parries or dodges at first, then they get into a series of attacks and ripostes.

Dialogue.Line: You improve, Doctor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor does a series of feints which leaves his tip near Grendel's throat. Kurster watches from the doorway. The Doctor doesn't follow through, so they start again. Finally, the Doctor knocks the sword from Grendel's hand. After briefly having him at his mercy, he kicks the sword back to its owner. He turns his back and still parries Grendel's attack. Kurster leaves now, and Romana follows. Till tries to join in the fight, but Reynart stops him.

Dialogue.Line: Gate control.
Where is it?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Till points. Reynart dodges the Doctor and Grendel and crosses to a lever in the wall. He pulls it down.
The bolts slide back and the gate opens.

Dialogue.Line: He's done it! Come on!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Inside, the Doctor drives Grendel back with a series of energetic lunges. They end up in a tunnel.

Kurster enters, and laughs. Strella backs away. Romana enters, picks up a picture and jams the frame down over Kurster's head. With his arms pinned, Strella takes her water jug and breaks it over his head. Kurster staggers and falls.

Dialogue.Line: Who are you?
Well, that's a very long story.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor drives Grendel up some steps as the King's men deal with his guards.

Dialogue.Line: It's all over, Grendel. That's Zadek and his men. Listen! You might as well surrender now.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Grendel pushes the Doctor away and removes his helmet.

Dialogue.Line: Surrender? You forget, Doctor, I'm a Gracht. We never surrender.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He jumps up onto a parapet.

Dialogue.Line: Next time I shall not be so lenient!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Grendel throws down his sword and dives into the moat.

Dialogue.Line: Grendel, you forgot your hat!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Grendel swims away.
The guard commander has his sword at Till's throat.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, there you are. Everyone all right? Thank you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor throws his sword to Farrah.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor, I owe you my life. How can I repay you?
Oh, it was a pleasure to be of service.
Such swordsmanship. I never thought I'd live to see the day when anyone would beat Count Grendel.
Really? Why, was he supposed to be good?
He can jest after a fight like that.
Why not stay here? This castle and all its lands can be yours. Anything you care to name.
No, no, no, that's a very kind offer, Majesty, but I have a pressing engagement on the other side of the galaxy. Has anybody here seen Romana?
She followed Kurster out.
Kurster? What?
The Princess Strella!
Where?
In the dungeons!
What!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor grabs the sword back and runs out.

Dialogue.Line: No!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Romana is sitting at the tapestry.

Dialogue.Line: But there are so many different types of stitch. It must take years to learn the art.
It's really only a question of patience and a certain delicacy of touch. I'm sure you can manage it. Go on. That's right. Very good.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor enters.

Dialogue.Line: Don't move! I said, don't move. (to Romana) Ah, you must be Princess Strella.
Er, no. I'm Princess Strella.
How do you do. I'm delighted to meet you. Romana.
Right.
I'm so sorry to take your new friend away so soon, Miss, but we have some urgent business to attend to.
The segment!
Right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Romana rushes out, and the Doctor follows her. Reynart enters.

Dialogue.Line: Strella! You're safe.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They embrace, then kiss.

Dialogue.Line: And you're real.
Well?
Doctor, it was in here somewhere. It's disappeared.
Use the tracer.
Oh, right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Each time the signal gets strong, the Doctor moves away. She finally realises, and he takes it out of his pocket.

Dialogue.Line: Ah!
Very funny.
You were very careless. I found it when I came in here. Come on, let's go.
Do you know, I'll be quite sorry to leave Tara.
What? Sorry to leave Tara? I didn't even catch one fish. Not one! Come on!
Doctor! Talking of forgetting things, where's K9?
Well, he. Where's K9?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor calls out over the moat.
Below, a little boat drifts in the current.

Dialogue.Line: Master. Master!
